notes: Approval manifest for blog images. Approve candidates in /admin/image-approvals, then download and replace this file.

candidates.alt: Hawker Hurricane prototype and early service imagery
candidates.caption: Above shows the Battle of Britain Memorial flight Hurricane (front) leading the Spitfire (back) in the skies over Southern Britain
Above are 174 Hurricane Sqn at Manston

Hurricane Mk IIC PZ865, “The Last of the Many!”, on an early test flight in 1944, being flown by Hawker’s Chief Test Pilot, the hatless George Bulman, who had flown the maiden flight of the prototype Hurricane, K5083, on 6th November 1935.

Hawker Hurricane production at Canadian Car & Foundry during the Spring of 1941. The supply of Rolls-Royce Merlin engines was a perennial problem until Packard began producing its US equivalent. Note how only the Hurricane in the foreground has an engine and propeller. This was likely just a dummy set up to ensure that everything fitted properly prior to the airframe's delivery - the engine and propeller being dismounted for trial in subsequent airframes once fettling was complete.

Charlie Barton, with his movie camera, in a Bristol fighter F2B of the New Zealand Permanent Air Force. Taken in September 1928, on the occasion of Charles Kingsford Smith's aerial crossing of the Tasman.
13th Squadron (Attack) - Dayton-Wright XB-1A, Kelly Field, Texas, 1921.
A Bristol F.2 Fighter preserved at the Imperial War Museum Duxford

candidates.title: Beardmore Parkhead Forge
candidates.caption: Beardmore’s Parkhead Forge and related works underpinned the company’s aviation contributions.
The staff of Bay 3 Machine Section at William Beardmore & Co's Howitzer Department, Parkhead, during the First World War.
Beardmore - The Completed constructional shed, Inchinnan, Scotland

candidates.title: Spitfire assembly line
candidates.alt: Spitfire assembly line at Supermarine works in Southampton during WWII
candidates.caption: Spitfire assembly line at Supermarine works in Southampton, showing the precision jigs and fixtures that enabled mass production of high-quality aircraft.

candidates.title: Women working on aircraft assembly
candidates.alt: Women working on aircraft assembly line during WWII
candidates.caption: Women workers on aircraft assembly line, 1943. The wartime workforce expansion brought skilled women into critical manufacturing roles.

candidates.title: Aircraft production factory
candidates.alt: Aircraft production factory showing jigs and fixtures
candidates.caption: Aircraft production factory showing the sophisticated jigs and fixtures that ensured geometric accuracy across thousands of airframes.

candidates.title: Quality control inspection
candidates.alt: Quality control inspection of aircraft components during WWII
candidates.caption: Quality control inspection using calibrated gauges and measurement tools to ensure every component met exacting standards.
